Award.AwardTitle: TUES: Motivating Students in an Introductory Continuous-Time Signals and Systems Course Using a Novel Signals Exploration Platform

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Description
This project is researching the hypothesis that motivation and learning in an introductory continuous time signals and systems (CTSS) course will improve if the theoretical presentation of material is augmented with weekly, sensory-based, application-oriented experiences. Laboratory exercises are being developed that are based on a hardware platform designed for measuring and processing realistic continuous-time signals. Summative assessments including surveys, focus groups, and specific rubrics applied to final exams are being used to measure changes in motivation and learning, in conjunction with baseline data that has been collected over a three-year period. The project incorporates learning theory in the development of materials to support student learning of the difficult engineering content that is associated with signals and systems related courses. Open-source modules are being produced that have a high potential for broad adoption. The effort also involves a comprehensive evaluation plan that is producing the data needed to convince others that they should consider adopting the platform.


Broader Significance
The process that is being utilized in creating signals and systems content is informing the development of other introductory engineering course modules. A workshop is being developed and will be held at national conferences in which the participants will get to perform some of the laboratory exercises and keep the platform that they use. Furthermore, dissemination of the assessment results and materials is also being distributed through national conferences and journal publications. The outreach activities of the project have further potential to positively impact K-12 students and interest them in pursuing careers in engineering. In addition to the focus on CTSS courses, the platform is being utilized in a K-12 outreach program called Explore Engineering (at Rose-Hulman). The materials developed for the program introduce middle/high-school students to the concept of frequencies in relation to music, sounds, and electrocardiograph (ECG) signals. These materials are available to the public and the experiences are informing the development of further outreach activities and collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this work was to gain a better understanding of the difficulties that engineering students face in introductory continuous-time signals and systems (CTSS) courses. At the host institution, this course has the highest drop failure rate in the whole Electrical and Computer Engineering curriculum. Anecdotal evidence indicates that the drop/failure rate for this subject is similar at many other schools. An experiment was designed and conducted in which students were given a series of conceptual questions that required a thorough understanding of CTSS concepts in order to answer them correctly. The students answered the questions in a think-out-loud fashion during a one-on-one interview setting with the experimenter. The audio and video of the interviews were recorded and any student writing was kept. The data from nineteen such interviews suggested nine problematic reasonings that were grouped into three broad categories: Signal Representations and Operations, Frequency Analysis, and System Analysis. The full descriptions of these misconceptions and possible explanations were published in a Ph.D. dissertation and are still being developed in order to submit for publication in the literature.

The topics covered in an introductory CTSS course are relevant to almost every area in electrical and computer engineering. As such, it is difficult to find a curriculum that does not contain at least one required course on this subject. While this work was specific to a CTSS course, the root of the problem is applicable to any introductory course that is highly mathematical and theoretical in any engineering discipline. One possible reason for the misconceptions is that students have very little prior experience of CTSS concepts on which to build. While students use cell phones and WiFi on a daily basis, they have no comprehension of the signals involved as superimposed waves of different frequencies.

In order to provide experiences that could help students identify and resolve the misconceptions that were discovered through the student interviews, a novel hardware platform and associated activities were developed. This hardware platform is truly continuous-time by employing only analog circuits; it facilitates the construction of simple systems such as filters, samplers, and modulators; and it provides many different signal inputs such as the students’ own ECG and voice as well as high-impedance inputs for function generators. For almost all students at the host institution, using this platform was the first time they interacted with real-world signals and observed what happened to the signals in both the time and frequency domains as they interacted with different systems. Both the hardware and associated activities were vetted in the classroom through several years of revision during this NSF grant. The cost for making the hardware platform was kept below $200 in order to make it accessible to other schools. The plans for making the platform and the associated activities are available online at https://wordpress.rose-hulman.edu/signalprocessingeducation.

To help disseminate the materials, a workshop was developed in which the participants discussed the challenges of teaching CTSS courses as well as the data from the interviews, and they performed some of the laboratory exercises using the hardware platform. Four full or half-day workshops were held at national conferences, and three three-day workshops were held at the host institution. During the full or half-day workshops, attendees were able to interact with the hardware on a limited basis or participate in demonstrations. During the three-day workshops, participants created their own experiments and were able to take the hardware platform with them. Over 64 contacts were made through these workshops, and five schools have either purchased or received hardware platforms through this NSF grant and are using them for instruction in their CTSS courses.
